Review_body: The book by Daphne Du Maurier is amazing and a favourite, a masterpiece of suspenseful atmosphere and psychological depth. There are three versions of 'Rebecca' prior to this latest one from 2020, the best known one justifiably being the Alfred Hitchcock directed film. While the 70s adaptation with Jeremy Brett is the best version as an adaptation, Hitchcock's is my personal favourite. Even with inevitable changes to suit the code, it is superbly made, acted (Judith Anderson is unforgettable) and directed, true in spirit to the book's atmosphere.Unfortunately, this version is inferior in nearly all those aspects. It does have its good things, but of all the four versions of 'Rebecca' it is easily the worst for me. Being the only one to not work, the other three are excellent and more. Visually and stylistically, this 'Rebecca' is mostly very successful. When it comes to the substance however, this film adaptation and standalone wise is a failure. Actually don't think one needs to have seen any of the previous versions or read the book to see how badly flawed the film is, a friend of mine also saw it with no prior knowledge of the source material or previous adaptations and disliked it too, highlighting the lack of atmosphere, shallow characterisation, erratic pacing, messy final act and Armie Hammer as particular flaws.'Rebecca' (2020) has good things. It does look gorgeous, though in my mind the film would have benefitted from a darker look either in a Gothic or noir-ish sense. The film is exquisitely photographed and the settings have beauty and vivid atmosphere, especially in Monte Carlo. Apart from the yellow suit, the costumes are nice and Manderlay is a beautiful and atmospheric house if not quite the character of its own kind that the previous three adaptations achieved. Clint Mansell's score has parts where it is ominous and stirs the emotions.Didn't care for the performances on the whole, but Kristin Scott Thomas is very good indeed as Mrs Danvers and there is a formidable quality that makes her very memorable. Sam Reilly's Favell is deceptively friendly but suitably manipulative, though could have afforded to have been more caddish.However, Lily James and Hammer didn't do it for me in their roles. Actually like James as an actress, ever since her charming 'Cinderella', but she lacks the plain mousiness that is needed for the 2nd Mrs De Winter and comes over as too neurotic in her more haunted moments. Hammer is also too young (especially considering that there is meant to be a big age difference, without it the story dynamic doesn't work) and too handsome, personality wise he is like a bland uncharismatic cipher as well as jerk-ish even when Maxim's character writing darkens. The lack of chemistry between the two really hurts the film and too lukewarm romantic comedy-like instead of the conflicted one it ought to be. The characters are stripped of their complexity and become one-dimensional, the most interesting is Mrs Danvers easily but that is down to Thomas mainly.Furthermore, the script could have flowed more and is too mundane with no spark. Some of it was awkward too. The direction is too constrained and tends to be pedestrian in the first half and then out of control and too reliant on a horror vibe in the second. The story is completely lacking in suspense and the omnipresent spookiness just isn't there, with the psychology of the characters being too muted. Likewise with the more mysterious elements in the story. The pacing is a mess too, it takes too long to get going and is too deliberate in the first half and then the final act especially becomes very rushed and jumpy. This part of the film is also far too melodramatic, the tone shift is not just completely uneasy and jarring but the second half feels like a different film altogether and in a schlocky horror way, not in a suspensefully psychological way. The ending is very tacked on and did reek of studio interference or of the writers not being sure how to end the film.In summary, liked the style but the substance underwhelms. Very disappointing. 4/10.

It beats me why directors and studios keep insisting on remaking, reimagining and reworking the old classics that don't need touching in the first place. REBECCA (2020) is a case in point: Hitchcock already did the definitive version of the Daphne du Maurier story back in 1940 despite changing the book slightly, and this new Netflix adaptation doesn't even come close. It's REBECCA for the DOWNTON ABBEY crowd, and lead actress Lily James - a DOWNTOWN alumnus herself - puts in a woefully bland turn as the lead, a far cry from Joan Fontaine's performance finesse in the Hitchcock film.Directorial duties are handed to British director Ben Wheatley, still generating a lot of goodwill a decade after KILL LIST; personally I find him hugely overrated, but I know he has a lot of fans. At its heart, the novel is a rich gothic mystery and a unique spin on the ghost or haunted house genre; more psychological and realistic than supernatural, but just as affecting. Here, there's little mystery and no atmosphere at all; you don't feel a thing. The sets and costumes look good, as they always do in modern historicals, but the writing is uneven at best. The only thing that made an impression on me was Armie Hammer's lead and that was for all the wrong reasons; check this guy's Twitter account if you want to find out more about him, but let's just say he's hardly a romantic hero.

The protagonist (Lily James) is a companion-assistant to rich abusive Mrs. Van Hopper (Ann Dowd) traveling in Monte Carlo. They encounter wealthy man-about-town Maxim de Winter (Armie Hammer). He falls for the poor orphan young girl and they get married. He is still haunted by his first wife Rebecca who died in a boating accident. They return to his large estate Manderley with a vast cast of servants led by the harsh Mrs. Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas).It's interesting that the lead character remains nameless. I've never read the Daphne du Maurier novel. I always assumed that her novels are pulpy romances. It probably meant that the book was written in a first person point of view putting the reading in the young assistant's shoes. It's a great way to get the female readers to embody the protagonist and walk her journey. I wonder if the movie should try doing something as experimental as strictly using the first person point of view. It does need something. As it stands, it's a rather old style melodramatic narrative. There are some attempt at gothic horror. The film looks beautiful. The actors are fine. In the end, nothing is superior or new or punch you in the face. It's fine.

Slick and pretty, but lacking any real spark. I know the Hitchcock movie so well, I couldn't help comparing at every turn. The former had so much atmosphere. There was something plodding about this one. What lies beneath in the first is all on the surface here. As the second wife changes, there is an abruptness that causes too much change in too short a time. The "gaslighting" that we suspect is at work in Hitchcock's version, isn't really there. I never asked myself, "Just what is Max up to?" Worth a look, but didn't need to be made.

Dame Kristin Scott Thomas follows in the footsteps of Dame Judith Anderson and Dame Diana Rigg as Mrs Danvers.Unfortunately Armie Hammer has to follow Laurence Olivier, Jeremy Brett and Charles Dance. Well let's say that unlike Dance who was too old for the role. Hammer is about the age that Oliver was when he played Maxim de Winter.The story is about a lowly young woman (Lily James) who has a whirlwind romance in the south of France with wealthy widower widower Maxim de Winter.When the newly married Mrs de Winter arrives to his ancestral home Manderley. She finds that her naivety is exposed by Mrs Danvers, the sinister housekeeper who was hopelessly devoted to Rebecca, the first Mrs de Winter who died in a tragic boating accident about a year before.It is a beginning of mind games between the two characters while Maxim seems to be haunted himself by Rebecca.Director Ben Wheatley has form with low budget English folk horror films. He also directed Peter Capaldi's feature length debut story of Doctor Who.With the help of a Netflix budget. Wheatley focuses more on the courtship in the South of France. There is a folk song played as the couple travel to Manderley which I thought will lead to an eerie Gothic atmosphere.There is a more lesbian subtext regarding Mrs Danvers and her infatuation with Rebecca.Somehow this is rather old fashioned. It is better than the 1997 ITV mini series but I expected more of Wheatley's own stamp.

This is a movie based on a novel - it is also or I would consider it a remake of Hitchcocks version of the source novel. Now I say that without having read the novel - but having seen the movie that had its 80th Birthday when this was released. Maybe this was meant to honor that Birthday.Whatever the case, if you only watch one of the two movies, I'd tell you to watch the Hitchcock version. While this does a bit of an update (and kind of changes a couple of things ... sort of), the original is better.Having said that, this had a great source and did not destroy that. By having a really good director and a good cast at hand, it manages to do a good movie. And when I say it changes things ... most are shuffled around dialog and scenes. It does seem to keep the spirit and the theme of the original.The tweaks are meant to make certain things better ... which you can question - or you may like the changes. The ending is different - and there is a mirroring on the fate of someone close to Rebecca ... which might make more sense than what the original did with the character ... again, this will depend on your own sentiment. Not many will watch the "same" movie twice anyway.A neat update, but Hitchcock did it better.

Review title: Pretty good, perhaps missing a little something.
Review_body: I had such high hopes for this, anticipation was high, especially as new material has been somewhat thin on the ground this year, for obvious reasons.I did raise an eyebrow when I heard that Armie Hammer had been cast as Maxim, but I felt he did a decent job, it gives me hope for his upcoming part in Death on the Nile.The standout for me was Kristin Scott Thomas, she was a fearsome Mrs Danvers, very impressive.The film itself, very stylish, and had some good moments. If I'm totally honest, I was a tad disappointed, I think the pacing was a bit off, it perhaps felt a bit rushed at the ending.A few reviewers calling for no remakes, and yes the 1940 adaptation is the ultimate, but come on, many of us love seeing a retelling. However, if you haven't seen the adaptation with Olivier and Fontaine, I urge you to, it captures the atmosphere beautifully.Overall, it's a good watch, maybe it's the sinister atmosphere that's perhaps lacking. 6/10.

Most people would recall the original black-and-white Alfred Hitchcock classic, based on the book by Daphne Du Maurier, well this new adaptation brings the action into colour, directed Ben Wheatley (Kill List, Sightseers, Free Fire). Basically, whilst in Monte Carlo, working for Mrs. Van Hopper (The Handmaid's Tale's Ann Dowd), an inexperienced young woman (Lily James) meets aristocratic widower George Fortescue Maximilian "Maxim" de Winter (Armie Hammer). The two spend a good deal of time together, leading to love and marriage. Maxim takes his new bride back to Manderley, his grand mansion by the sea in south-western England. She meets the housekeeper, Mrs. Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas), a domineering and cold woman obsessed with the memory of the first Mrs. De Winter, the eponymous Rebecca. Mrs. Danvers has preserved Rebecca's former grand bedroom and continues to display various items that carry her monogram (the letter "R"). The spiritual presence of Rebecca causes Mrs. De Winter to believe that Maxim is still in love with his first wife. Jack Favell (Sam Riley), Rebecca's cousin comes to visit, which angers Maxim. It is only later, talking to Maxim's sister Beatrice Lacy (Keeley Hawes), that Mrs. De Winter discovers what happened to Rebecca; she died out at sea after her vessel capsized, and her body was washed ashore sometime later. Wanting to please her husband, Mrs. De Winter suggests holding a costume ball as he and Rebecca used to. Mrs. De Winter's personal maid Clarice (Bryony Miller) suggests a dress worn by a young woman in one of the portraits displayed on the staircase, implied to be one of Maxim's ancestors. But, when Mrs. De Winter comes down the staircase wearing the costume, the guests are shocked, and Maxim is furious as Rebecca wore an identical dress at her last ball. Realiaing that Mrs. Danvers had manipulated Clarice, and believing that Maxim now regrets their marriage, Mrs. De Winter has a small breakdown. Mrs. Danvers reveals her contempt for the new Mrs. De Winter, believing she is trying to replace Rebecca. She tries to convince a helpless and disturbed Mrs. De Winter to jump to her death from the window. At that moment, however, the alarm is raised because a boat has been discovered, brought ashore by a storm. The boat is Rebecca's, and her body has been identified aboard. The investigation of Rebecca's death is reopened, and Maxim is suspected of murder. Maxim confesses to his new wife that he misidentified another body as Rebecca's in order to conceal the truth. He hated Rebecca, who was cruel, selfish, adulterous, and manipulative and the marriage had been a sham from the start. She pretended to be the perfect wife and hostess for the sake of appearances. On the night of her death, Rebecca told Maxim that she was pregnant with another man's child. She placed his gun to her chest and stated that the only way to be free of her was to kill her. Enraged, Maxim pulled the trigger, then disposed of her body, placing it in her boat and sinking it. Despite his confession, Mrs. De Winter is relieved to know that Maxim loves her and resolves to support him during the investigation. Favell attempts to blackmail Maxim, claiming to have a written note from Rebecca as proof that she did not commit suicide. The trial shows Rebecca's boat to have been deliberately sunk. In the court, Mrs. Danvers implies that a visit by Rebecca to a doctor was linked to her pregnancy, and Maxim's check written to Favell for the note is shown. Maxim is placed under arrest for murder. Mrs. De Winter fires Danvers and locates Rebecca's doctor, Dr. Baker (Bill Paterson). Reading her file reveals that Rebecca could not have been pregnant because she had advanced and incurable cancer and she would have died within a few months. An investigator concludes Rebecca committed suicide by scuttling her boat, while Mrs. De Winter privately concludes that Rebecca wanted Maxim to kill her. Absolved, Maxim and Mrs. De Winter drive home. Returning to Madeley, they are shocked to see the mansion on fire. A maid reveals that Mrs. Danvers started the fire and fled. Mrs. De Winter races to the cliffs and finds Mrs. Danvers standing at the edge. She pleads with Mrs. Danvers not to jump, but Mrs. Danvers curses her and Maxim to never know happiness and jumps into the sea and drowns. Years later, Mrs. De Winter is with Maxim, as they search for their dream home. Also starring Tom Goodman-Hill as Frank Crawley, Ben Crompton as Ben, Jane Lapotaire as Granny, and Mark Lewis Jones as Inspector Welch. James is good as the quivering wife, Hammer is a little blank as the husband, but at least Scott Thomas is as always reliable as the sinister housemaid. Like the original, it is a film of two halves, the first about the new wife trying and failing to fit in, and the second the truth about the first wife's death being exposed, it really makes the most of the use of colour, from the emaculate costumes and lavish locations, and it has terrific camerawork and a splendid score by Clint Mansell. It does not have quite have the same eerie atmosphere and psychological element as the original, but it an interesting enough romantic thriller. It was nominated the BAFTA for Best Production Design. Worth watching!

I reckon we ought to set up a panel of worthy people to whom producers must apply when they want to make a remake of a classic - "King Kong" or "Psycho" or... "Rebecca". If they cannot convince them that there is any point in a "reimagining", then they don't get to make it...! That way, we might be spared sterile, charm free efforts like this from Ben Wheatley. True, the camera loves both Lily James and Armie Hammer, and Dame Kristin Scott Thomas is always a formidable screen presence; but this just lacks any sense of suspense or menace. The costumes and scenery are all beautiful, but these depictions of Dame Daphne du Maurier's torn and tortured characters are as flat as a flounder with the dialogue frequently over-forced to the point that I wanted to cringe. The effects are really pretty poor - especially at the end, too, and all in all it has straight to tv written all over it!

This was poorly portrayed as a thriller/mystery, when in fact it wasn't much more than a lifeless drama. It wasn't enough of anything to even categorize. Cinematography was beautiful, but acting was only okay. Characters had no depth and the storyline was only moderately interesting.

Each version of Rebecca has it's pros and cons. The Hitchcock version with Lawrence Olivier and Joan Fontaine is just too dated by today's standards. I used to think the 1979 version with Jeremy Brett and Anna Massey was fine. The acting was good and the story effectively told. But nobody was very attractive in that version so it was interesting to see an updated 2020 version with such A list actors as the lead characters. Lily James is such an animated actress she makes anything seem involving. That's why the first part of the show is watchable and her romance is nice to watch. There is more passion than they could have shown in the earlier versions. The tinted view of the South of France is beguiling. But during the court case and the ending there is a lack of intensity and the story feels dated and rushed. The reveal from Maxim about Rebecca's death is weak and unclear. Armie Hammer looks right for these classic older stories. Maybe it's the 30s costume but he looks more than usual like a giant. He isn't quite tortured enough and maybe because he doesn't have a British accent or even put one on he seems less effective during the intense moments.
The settings are nice from the South of France to the coast line in England to the interiors of the country house. The house didn't feel creepy like in the 79 version. But the director used too much dark lighting maybe unaware at that time that everything would be on TV these days instead of the cinema. Kristin Scott Thomas isn't menacing enough as Mrs Danvers - maybe because she is still beautiful even though she is older.
Despite the flaws fans of the story will want to check out this 2020 version.

Review title: Unsuccessful modern take on renowned tale
Review_body: STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday MorningA young woman (Lily James) becomes a 'social assistant' to a snobby older posh lady, only to catch the eye of Maxim de Winter (Arnie Hammer), a renowned figure on the social scene. Before long, she has become Mrs. de Winter, and moved in to Manderlay, Maxim's stately home, although her new husband is strangely guarded on certain things. All of a sudden, strange occurances begin taking place, which seem to be initiated by Mrs. Danvers (Kristen Scott Thomas), the resident housekeeper, all threatening to reveal a secret too terrifying for words.For such an avid film watcher, I must confess to being far less cultured than I would like to admit, and so with a touch of embarrassment, I must say this is the first incarnation of Daphne Du Maurier's well regarded novel Rebecca that I have seen. My first experience of hearing 'last night, I dreamt again of Manderlay', and 'the second Mrs. de Winter' and of Mrs. Danvers, alas with a modern spin by director Ben Wheatley, adding his distinctive touch. But sadly, even he can't bring this old tale into present times.There's always some potential in bringing an enduring tale in to present times, but the old Hollywood style and period dialogue just comes off as alienating to a present day film viewer, not acquainted with the story or the timeframe it exists in. As a result, it just lingers on for the most part, failing to really engage or draw you into the story, only really coming to life in the final half. It captures the fashions and style of the time quite well, and does generate some intrigue, but not really enough to last all the way.It might have helped if I had as much affection for the tale as Wheatley obviously has, and maybe if I saw some different versions of it, I might think of it differently, but this modern update of it simply leaves me cold. **

'Rebecca' is a romantic thriller, set in the 1930s (when Daphne Du Maurier wrote the novel on which it is based) and with at leasr three distinct plot twists; it was famously filmed by Hitchcock. It's characters move in a monied world and Ben Wheatley's new version certainly looks luscious; it's also put together very nicely: the timing is well-judged, and the level of creepy atmospherics is judged just right). There's also a interesting "feminism gone wrong" vibe behind the devotion her former servant shows for the absent title character. The film's biggest failing is the presentation of final twist, which is slightly botched (the book's Wikipedia page will make clear what the film does not convey).

Review title: So much better than I expected.
Review_body: Whatever you do, don't approach Ben Wheatley's new film "Rebecca" as a remake of Alfred Hitchcock's much beloved classic, not that it ever would have been; Wheatley is his own man and we always knew he would do things differently, in this case sticking more closely to the book and casting it in such a way as to banish all memories of Fontaine, Olivier and Dame Judith and in this he has been largely successful. Armie Hammer is a lot less melancholy, if a tad modern, than Lord Larry ever was. Lily James is much more down-to-earth and obviously a good deal more sensual than Joan while Kristin Scott Thomas gives Mrs. Danvers a human side that was totally lacking in Judith Anderson's performance. Indeed, regardless of what else you think of the film I doubt if anyone could find fault with Scott Thomas who effortlessly walks away with the picture.It also benefits from a Manderley that really looks like it might be one of the finest houses in all of England and the whole thing is beautifully shot by Laurie Rose in widescreen and colour. Fans of Mr. Hitchcock's version are unlikely to be won over; however, newcomers and fans of Du Maurier's novel should find plenty here to please them though the device of not giving the new Mrs. De Winter a Christian name seems even more contrived this time round.

I see some critics musing over "Rebecca," ostensibly an adaptation of Daphne du Maurier's novel, but cinematically marked as a remake and overshadowed by Alfred Hitchcock's Best Picture Oscar winner of 1940, why it was made, which is to suggest that it shouldn't have been made at all. Maybe not by those who made it, but I think conceptually the idea of remaking this particular adaptation was potentially clever. More so than "Psycho" (1960 and 1998), at least. The Gothic narrative is all about a house haunted by its deceased former occupant and a marriage overshadowed by a former one--read: Hitchcock is the Rebecca to this 2020 Netflix movie. Perhaps, not unlike how "Jane Eyre" was the Rebecca to the book "Rebecca" itself.This "Rebecca," though, feels more as though it were haunted by "Downton Abbey." It surely has the air of superficial Anglophilia for class structures--the turgid cross-class romantic fairy tale, the upstairs-downstairs, masters-and-servants melodrama--about it. We get plenty of period detail, lovely costumes and some glorious architecture, and it's often pictorially pleasant, but it doesn't appear to be leveraged at the helm in any interesting manner. It merely comes across as pretty and bland as the acting of Lily James and Armie Hammer. Kristin Scott Thomas is better. But, it's like her character's thaumatrope instead of the 1940 picture's film-within-a-film scene; the elements are drawn out, but there's nothing to animate the material. We get static characterizations and slight, unnecessary or otherwise counterproductive story alterations; the epilogue is particularly bad and not the one from the book and which was wisely dropped in the 1940 film. This where there was once a landmark in cinematographic exploration of architecture and space that haunted, including influencing "Citizen Kane" (1941). This 2020 version doesn't haunt; it'll be forgotten.

Review title: Decent drama thriller that could have been so much more but is left feeling empty.
Review_body: 3 out of 5 stars.Rebecca is a fair drama thriller film that is beautiful to look at with the set locations, cinematography, and Ben Wheatly trying to deliver a mystery thriller direction. But it does feel short handed with surprises and twists. Which the film is short on surprises. Which many may not be surprised.The plot follows Lily James character as she runs into Maxim (Armie Hammer) who owns an estate. They both fall for each other. When Lily is being driven away. Maxim proposes to her. Which they get married and she moves into the estate. She soon finds out he is a widow after his former wife was lost at sea. And apparently drowned. When Mrs. Danvers (Kristen Scott Thomas) is rude and unwelcoming to her. She discovers that there is so much more that she does not know.It was a decent plot. Starting out as Lily James is a girl that wants to travel. And takes the companionship as a job to get her to travel. Until she runs into Armie Hammers character which the films direction becomes like a romantic drama film. Except Hammers character has an attitude every time she brings up about his former wife who passed away. Or avoids talking about his past. The plot does change gears in the final half hour when the twist is revealed. And it becomes something more of a serious drama. Which is also where it disappoints with a twist that feels a little short handed.Lily James is lovable as Mrs. de Winters. She is sweet and curious. It is difficult to not like her character. James delivers a great performance. Armie Hammer is good as Maxim. Playing a mysterious character which he is struggling with his past. Kristen Scott Thomas is okay playing Mrs. Danvers. Who looks disgusted every time she sees Mrs. de Winters.Ben Wheatly does deliver a beautiful cinematography and tone with the set locations. And trying to build an eerie bleak mystery. But it lacks momentum or thrills.

Review title: A dull new take on the Rebecca tale
Review_body: Since announcing himself with the horror treat that was Kill List all the way back in 2011, English director Ben Wheatley has struggled to recapture the goodness that was found in his breakout cult hit with films that offer tantalizing glimpses into the director that could be but never form into the cohesive whole that would undeniably encase the talented artist into the top line of modern day auteurs.Based on both the classic Daphne Du Maurier novel and the renowned Alfred Hitchcock film of the same name, Wheatley's reimagining of gothic thriller Rebecca seemed like an intriguing choice for the director who has previously steered very clear from more mainstream content and while its great to see Wheatley hold back from his usual gratuitous violence and dark humor, this pretty looking Netflix period piece may look the part but its a cold and drab affair in most instances, making one wonder why exactly Wheatley and his creative team felt the need to give Rebecca a fresh coat of paint at all.Teaming up beautiful stars Armie Hammer and Lily James to play the titular Mr and Mrs de Winter, things start off well enough as the two begin a courtship that leads to a quickfire marriage and a rushing back to Hammer's Maxim's lavish manner in England that is run by Kristin Scott Thomas's scheming Mrs. Danvers in the wake of Maxim's trauma due to the loss of his previous wife Rebecca, but Wheatley's film never finds a comfortable groove as it fails to capture its romance angle or its mystery/thriller angles and instead gets lost in a lot of eye pleasing and solid production values but not a whole lot of anything else.For such a horror obsessed director, its curious that Wheatley wasn't able to instill his own brand of devilishly inventive scares or chills into Du Maurier's oft-imitated tale as Rebecca for the most part remains thrill free throughout with the scariest thing throughout some odd sleepwalking and some creepy stares.Without these chills and thrills Hammer and James have a lot of work to do as the seemingly mismatched couple and the two charismatic performers aren't able to elevate proceedings a whole lot with the initial wins they have as head over heels lovers quickly giving way to a hum-drum series of procedurals that wont surprise or entertain anyone that's ever seen or read a tale of this ilk before and at days end, we come to an overarching sense that we just don't care enough about these two characters as Rebecca draws slowly towards its end game.Final Say -A pretty to look at but otherwise lifeless redo of the Rebecca tale, Ben Wheatley once more fails to capture the magic of his early career work in what is another disappointment in his growing collection of mid to low-tier of films.2 Oyster breakfasts out of 5

A romance that embarked on police suspense in the final stretch in an irresistible way, plus an excellent Netflix production... What a beautiful film, I want to see the 40 version, it must be fantastic, adorable...

So this film is a remake of the famous film directed by the legendary Alfred Hitchcock of the same name and has now made its way to Netflix and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees a young newlywed arrive at her husbands family estate where the legacy of his former wife Rebecca remains.Main Character
Lily James has been in the news lately for some pretty bad things but let's just talk about her performance in this film and unfortunately I didn't care about her character at all. She is just so dull and she never seems like a human being, she is either overacting every scene or just moping about. Also her character is so inconsistent, it is tough to explain without spoilers but she makes some decisions that just feel very strange and like they don't fit with what we have seen throughout the ret of the film.Supporting Characters
Kristen Scott Thomas plays the head maid in the house and I thought she did a good job, she is very chilling and stern in the film, she comes across as a dastardly person and she just does a good job at it here. Sam Riley who I like as an actor has a small role here and I thought he did a good job, it's just a shame that he doesn't have more screen time and more to do here. Armie Hammer plays the husband in this film and he didn't do much for me, he also was a dull character, that I never cared about him or their relationship. They just lacked chemistry and the problem is that neither of them gave me a reason to care about them and this relationship that we are meant to be rooting for.Story
The story in the film has some interesting things in it, especially towards the end of the film as more is revealed about what exactly is going as reveals get made and things get more crazy. But none of it really matters, it is very jumbled and not expanded upon, it is like the film meanders so much for the first half of the film that it has to rush the last act and it is clear to see with a truly awful ending.Script
The script isn't very good, there is no memorable bits of dialogue and nothing that fleshes out these characters. As I said earlier the writing is so poor and rushes lots of its plot to the 3rd act which makes you confused.Style
The best part of this film is that it is really nice to look at, it has great costumes, great locations and great visuals and that is about it. This is a really slow film that feels 3 hours when it is only 2, with not much going on it just feels like a real slog to get through.Overall
Overall, this is a really poor film and shows why sometimes remakes and reboots are just unnecessary unless it is going to be done to a high quality. Save yourself 2 hours and skip this one.

Review title: A bit intense at the end, but overall full of boring conversation, and annoying overuse scene! Should have done better!
Review_body: This film start with the narrator talking about the manor "Manderley", and her employer "Van Hopper" scene! As turnout, this film is about solving the mystery of the death of Rebecca! Rebecca actually kill by her husband "Maxim", but eventually overturn by suicide! Entire film full of boring conversation, and annoying overuse scene! Such as, overuse of the annoying song playing at the background scene, overuse of the dreaming scene, overuse of the kissing scene, overuse the passing note scene, and overuse of the dining scene! Make the film unwatchable! Barely intense scene is, Manderley been burned by Mrs. Danvers at the end! At the end, Maxim release from the jail after proving Rebecca kill herself by Mrs. de Winter! Maxim and Mrs. de Winter move to Cairo at the very end! That's it! Another disappointed film!

Mega rich Maxim De Winter (Hammer) falls and marries young and shy Lily James and they move to his vast estate, Manderley where the spirit of his previous wife, Rebecca looms large, thanks in no small part to the efforts of Rebecca's loyal servant Mrs Danvers (Scott Thomas).Comparisons with Hitchcock's Oscar winner are inevitable and on the whole this sticks to that format, albeit it also follows more closely to Du Maurier's book particularly in the last third. The issue here is the 2 principal leads - Hammer gets overly aggressive and mysterious which lacks the subtlety of Olivier's performance and James is just far too wimpy. Scott Thomas though puts in a far less Gothic, but no less obsessive turn than Judith Anderson's original.Well worth a watch then for a good first and final act, shame about the middle, particularly the psychedelic ball, which is a mess.

Review title: Grimly atmospheric and dutifully Gothic, but...
Review_body: While his films might be an acquired taste, it cannot be denied that Ben Wheatley is one of the most unconventional voices in contemporary cinema. Personally, I love Ben Wheatley and have enjoyed all of his films to varying degrees (with High-Rise, Wheatley's most polarizing feature in a filmography full of them, being my favorite of his), one reason being that I find his unorthodox approach to filmmaking, in an era where it almost feels like idiosyncrasy in filmmaking is sadly dying, to be highly refreshing. However, given that multiple adaptations of Daphne du Maurier's Rebecca already exist, with the most famous one being the Best Picture winner directed by Alfred Hitchcock, I couldn't help but be highly curious as to what Wheatley would do with this project, and was even cautious after discovering that this is the first of Ben Wheatley's features to not be written by him or his writing partner Amy Jump. It certainly didn't help that the the trailer left much to be desired.That said, maybe I shouldn't have been worried, because even despite operating on a more accessible level, this new adaptation of Daphne du Maurier's acclaimed novel not only proves to be another stellar effort from an idiosyncratic filmmaker with an already commendable body of work, but is one that even improves on Hitchcock's film in various aspects.

Rebecca: This is not a horror film but with Ben Wheatley at the helm as Director you can be sure of a dark adaptation of Daphne du Maurier's classic novel. Lily James is the new Mrs de Winter and from her first arrival at Manderley ,the housekeeper Mrs Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas), makes her feel as if she is usurping the late Rebecca de Winter. Gaslighting of James continues, especially at the Ball she organises. Rebecca may be dead but her presence rules over the house. The film opens in Monte Carlo where James is a companion to a wealthy American, Mrs Van Hopper. The feel and cinematography at this stage is reminiscent of The Talented Mr Ripley. While James is no imposter she does suffer from imposter syndrome. When Maxim de Winter (Arnie Hammer) sweeps her off her feet and proposes marriage, Mrs Van Hopper tells her she is just a passing interest for him. This makes Danvers work all the easier. Wheatley has delivered a Gothic movie which touches on horror at times but the pacing is off. Too much is crammed into the second half of Rebecca with the all important revelations coming at us too quickly. It may not achieve classic status but it is both intriguing and entertaining. On Netflix. 8/10.

The recent Netflix remake of the 1940 Best Picture winner (directed by some clown named Alfred Hitchcock). Now starring Lily James & Armie Hammer (in the roles established by Joan Fontaine & Laurence Olivier) we find James working as a valet for a rich dowager (played by Ann Dowd looking unrecognizable), an American on vacation in Europe who's staying at a swank hotel. Unrehearsed in the ways of the world, James (working for a paltry 90 pounds a year) is pushed around & shoved to do her job waiting hand & foot on Dowd's behalf generally not enjoying the sumptuous surroundings about her but things change when the mysterious & rich, Maxim DeWinter, Hammer, shows up at the resort setting tongues a-wagging. Dowd, hoping to get into his good graces & probably dish some gossip, hopes to be seated w/Hammer when he goes to dine sending James as her emissary but in meet cute fashion Hammer does end up finding her to be the bee's knees & they start to date (Dowd falls sick & thankfully for James bedridden) which when their time at the hotel comes to an end the picture postcard sheen of their romance bears fruit when they marry. They then head to back to Hammer's estate, Manderlay, where the staff meets the new Mrs. DeWinter & the house matron, Mrs. Danvers, played by Kristin Scott Thomas, still exalts the name & memory of the former mistress (the Rebecca of the title who passed away when she drowned) keeping James on edge throughout her stay which forces her, whether she likes it or not, to assume the mantle she's married into & have some say over the household. Now the big elephant in the room can be addressed, was the original Rebecca so antiquated & past its prime it needed a remake? No way full stop. Does this film hurt the memory of the original? No, again. While hitting a lot of the same story beats as its predecessor, it also adds unnecessary subplots (maybe from Daphne Du Maurier's novel?) which end up adding nothing w/the awesome & iconic finale of Manderlay & Mrs. Danvers going up in flames changed to something a bit muted & less bombastic. The actors are fine but in no way do they outdo their betters but for those out there who deign to even glimpse a film prior to a certain date in their heads, this version may be the one they'll adore, for me I liked it, that's it.

I've always disliked narrative involving "nameless characters" but in this case I could make an exception, because the main female character is a shy, mousy type, so insignificant as not being worthy of a name.Lily James is totally miscast because she's not mousy enough; besides, her look is too modern: bushy eyebrows were not fashionable in the 30s and her haircut is also wrong.Not only she doesn't look the part but her acting is subpar. First she plays a fake ingenue, eager to have sex with a man she met a couple of days earlier, then in Manderley she goes through confusion, bewilderment and fear, all of which read on her face as if she is constipated.Hammer is wooden and not mysterious. First he seems to fall in lust almost immediately, then he "gets busy" the way men do and finally confesses to a crime like he's reading a shopping list.Scott Thomas is the best of the three, but it's not great compliment, considering how bad James and Hammer are. She is campy and not subtle at all.A further note of demerit goes to the ball scene, grotesque beyond belief and what's left is one point to the beautiful settings and one for the costumes - otherwise this remake is totally missable.

I went into watching Rebecca having never read the book or seen the Alfred Hitchcock movie , so I had no idea what the story was about and at the end I was left wondering what all the fuss was about ?A young newlywed arrives at her husband's imposing family estate on a windswept English coast and finds herself battling the shadow of his first wife, Rebecca, whose legacy lives on in the house long after her death.This has the feel of a really old story . Set at a time when the plot would have been quite controversial but sadly , in today's world , it feels really tame. I'm not convinced a Daphne Du Maurier novel has the pizazz required and I would have liked to have seen a modern day version.It looks fantastic as most Netflix films do . The house is quite spectacular.
The performances are perfectly fine . Probably the stand actor is Kristen Scott Thomas who does menacing brilliantly.

But the real problem I have is the story is dull . It's a little bit like a who done it, but without the intrigue and I kept thinking - There is going to be a great twist here - but the pay off never happened sadly.

Review title: The Phantom of the Soap Opera
Review_body: GRADE: C-THIS FILM IS NOT RECOMMENDED.IN BRIEF: The specter of Hitchcock haunts this soapy and dopey remake of his classic movie.JIM'S REVIEW: All marriages have their secrets and the recent nuptials of Maxim de Winter and our sweet naive heroine certainly do have their share in this unnecessary remake of Alfred Hitchcock's Oscar-winning classic, Rebecca. Gone is the Gothic mystery elements and romantic intrigue. Substituted now are period costumes and panoramic vistas one could find in a cheap Hallmark movie. No star leads now, just second-tier replicas in place of Sir Lawrence Olivier and Joan Fontaine. The only real mystery is why update this film in the first place.The movie starts off slowly with a whirlwind courtship along the coast of Monte Carlo with our two leads, Lily James and Armie Hammer. They do make a dashing couple. She, dressed in her Annie Hall best, complete with tennis racket, and he in his Gatsby-tailored finery. Their romance is silly and sun-baked, rarely believable. It takes nearly a half hour before they wed and head for Manderley, the stately estate once owned by the handsome Maxim and his former dead wife, Rebecca.The movie always looks stylish and picturesque, but never has any suspense or genuine menace. It's all Hollywood dress-up time. The direction by Ben Wheatley is adequate but not very accomplished. Mr. Wheatley seems more concerned with the expensive trappings than the main characters trapped in the film's conventional storytelling. Heavy-handed use of dream sequences are interspersed to bring tension throughout the film, but they only make the movie more ludicrous. The screenplay by Jane Goldman, Joe Shrapnel, and Anna Waterhouse covers the Daphne Du Maurier novel's dense plotting but without any finesse. The film seems perfectly content to focus on the soap opera contrivance and moves the mystery aside. Sorely missing is that Hitchcock touch and his concise adaptation of the Du Maurier best-selling novel, although this version does stay true to the novel's ending. But is that enough to justify this disappointing remake? (You already know my answer.)Mr. Hammer's interpretation of his role as Mr. de Winter is odd, more petulant child than the moody grieving widow. Ms. James lacks the vulnerability and innocence as the second Mrs. de Winter and she tends to over-emote in some crucial scenes. Both actors have done better work. Only Kristin Scott Thomas comes off unscathed. She never approaches the greatness of Judith Anderson's monstrous housekeeper, Mrs. Danvers, in the Hitchcock original, but she comes very close. Her highly controlled mannerisms and intense line delivery is splendid. Her early monologue revering her former employer is the film's emotional highlight.As the new bride become unhinged and manipulated by her dubious housekeeper, the melodramatic excesses go full throttle, all leading to a nightmarish gala that goes predictably off kilter. When the plot twists finally arrive and are revealed, one doesn't care a sixpence about this cockamamy soap opera love story or its doomed lovers. The plot may thicken, but this rich consommé is cinematic peasant stew compared to the superior 1940 Gothic thriller. In retrospect, this Rebecca never stood a ghost of a chance.

Review title: This movie never found it's pace
Review_body: With such a great cast, I expected this to be a better movie. I don't know if it was a poor screenplay or muddy direction but the film felt hectic, choppy and melodramatic. Review title: Good performances but a pale imitation of the Original
Review_body:
My Review- " Rebecca "My Score 6.5 /10I really was looking forward to this new version of Rebecca mainly because of the excellent cast that includes Lily James as the young and naive ladies maid who becomes the new Mrs De Winter and mistress of Mandalay. This is the role that earned Joan Fontaine her first Academy Award nomination in 1941.
Armie Hammer is suitably dashing as the troubled Maxime De Winter Master of Mandalay the stately mansion where Rebecca ended her days. This role was one of Sir Laurence Olivier's finest Screen performances and also won him an Academy Award Best Actor nomination.
Kristin Scott Thomas is very good as the deranged housekeeper of Mandalay Mrs Danvers who's obsession with her dead mistress Rebecca borders on psychotic. This role in the 1940 film version was brilliantly portrayed by Australian actress Dame Judith Anderson ,who was also nominated for Best Supporting Actress.
The Original 1940 film version of Daphne Du Maurier's best selling novel Rebecca did win the Best Motion Picture Oscar of 1941 and there's a good reason why ,it's a brilliant adaptation filmed in monochrome that suits the Gothic atmosphere of the novel.
This 2020 film version has been described as Downton Abbey on a bad day and I can understand why it's beautifully filmed and uses great locations but it's far from brilliant. Like the horrible 2017 remake of Daphne Du Maurier's My Cousin Rachel this version of Rebecca seems to me to be padded with new plot twists and a little dumbed down . The cast is excellent but I feel like most remakes of Classic films especially if the original was directed by Alfred Hitchcock it's almost impossible to make them work but this one is at least a good attempt.
They tried it with Psycho in 1998 with Gus Van Sant directing and it was a momentous flop this version of Rebecca is much better than that horrible remake of Psycho .
English Director Ben Wheatley certainly is no competition to Hitchcock and on checking his previous work I could see no justification for using him to direct such a famous remake.
It's at times a quite entertaining movie ,especially if you've never seen the original but it really has nothing to justify the expense and frankly all this great talent is wasted.
I did appreciate the little homage to Alfred Hitchcock's 1963 film "The Birds" , it couldn't have been accidental and did add a sense of foreboding but pleas don't remake that film.
The set designs costumes and homes in this new adaptation are beautiful
The first house used is the Jacobean-era Hatfield House in Hertfordshire, which was built in 1611 for Robert Cecil, a former statesman in the court of Queen Elizabeth I. Cranborne Manor in Dorset, originally built in 1207 as a hunting lodge, before being remodelled in the 17th century, also for Robert Cecil.
Loseley House, situated in 1,400 acres of countryside near Guildford in Surrey Petworth House in West Sussex, a late 17th-century Grade I listed country house, rebuilt in 1688 by Charles Seymour, 6th Duke of Somerset Osterley House is Isleworth, built in the 1570s for banker Sir Thomas Gresham Mapperton House, a Jacobean manor in Devon Blegberry Farm in Devon.
Shooting for the film also took place at Hartland Quay, a rocky seaside area on the North Devon coastline.
Rebecca is well worth a look ,you'll enjoy the performances and the settings but I much prefer the original film. One performance I really didn't like in this movie is the casting of Ann Dowd who was so evil as Aunt Lydia Clements in The Handmaid's Tale as Mrs Van Hopper the wealthy bitchy socialite who employs our young heroine narrator as her personal assistant. It's only a brief but important role at the beginning of the film .
Ann Dowd plays the character as an alcohol soaked broad and unlike Florence Bates in the original just comes across as dead common and left me wondering how she could ever have been accepted in high society.

Review title: Netflix's version of Rebecca is... weird.
Review_body: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free reviews, please follow my blog :)Netflix's Rebecca is based on the 1938's novel of the same name written by Daphne du Maurier, but it's not its first cinematic adaptation, which leads me to the following shameful statement: I've never seen the famous Alfred Hitchcock's version of this story (nor have I read the novel, but I firmly defend that this doesn't matter). It's the only film of Hitchcock's filmography to have received the Best Picture award, so I admit that I'm much at fault here. However, Ben Wheatley isn't directing a remake of the original movie, but rather another adaptation of the also incredibly popular novel. I was intrigued by the premise, and the cast is definitely convincing, so how did it go?If I had to choose one word to ultimately describe Rebecca right now, it would probably be... weird. More on this in a bit. Starting with the positives, Armie Hammer and Lily James share such vivid chemistry that it elevates the surprisingly compelling bond that their characters form. I write "surprisingly" because I'm not easily engaged in most romantic relationships in films, whether these are straight-up romances or mixed up with other genres, like comedy or, as in this case, horror/thriller. Nevertheless, Lily and Armie are able to capture perfectly the growing love interest in one another through the first act, which is entirely dedicated to develop and nurture the key relationship of the movie.This is something I sincerely appreciate: when filmmakers know how to control pacing and how much time should a particular character or storyline receive of build-up. Wheatley does an impressive job during the first half of the film by moving the characters and plot forward at the precise moment they need to. This allows the viewer to understand what the characters are genuinely feeling and why some narrative decisions are made that change the course of the story. Lily James offers a remarkable performance, just like Armie Hammer. Kristin Scott Thomas is also excellent, even though her character is part of my problems with the movie. However, it's the production design that stands out!The beautiful colors and striking landscapes of the French Riviera fill the screen with luxury and harmony during the naturally passionate beginning of the relationship. Once the narrative moves to Manderley, the tone changes to a gradually more depressing, dark environment, accompanied by a creepy score (Clint Mansell), and spooky nightmares. The adequate costumes also help to set the atmosphere, but the beginning of the second half is where things start to get extremely weird.From the very first moment the viewer sets place in Manderley, something is noticeably not right. Everyone addresses the late wife, Rebecca, as the most perfect human being to ever exist, reaching God-like compliments in a clear attempt of trying to create the cliche "previous wife was amazing, new one is awful, let's make her life a living hell" storyline. An expected development with exaggeratedly positive comments from the staff. However, it's the horror vibe that embraces the mansion that drives me nuts. Wheatley sets a dark, mysterious, even supernatural environment surrounding the house, a definitely intriguing aspect that leads to a hugely disappointing, hollow, unsatisfactory conclusion.From the first to the second act, the genre in display changes from a fun, lighthearted romance to a horror/thriller featuring a "haunted" mansion. The tone change is far from being smooth. However, the third act stores a drastic shift in pretty much everything: tone, genre, story, and even characters. I can't get into details, but it's the most incomprehensible decision in the entire film. The last act not only follows a path that comes from nowhere, but it's also incredibly rushed, concluding the movie in the most disjointed, convoluted way possible.It raises questions related to events and characters in the previous act, it treats Mrs. Danvers very poorly, and ends with a deceiving last shot that makes the viewer think "did I miss something?" when the answer is a clear "no, it's just a weird ending". Clint Mansell's score is captivating, but its timing is just completely off. It's this feeling of false uncertainty that leaves me frustrated. Why try to make a film about something that it's not? Why try to give Rebecca a horror vibe if it doesn't lead to any impactful outcome? I finished the movie with doubts that have no reason to exist simply because the question should have never been asked by the story in the first place...All in all, Netflix's version of Rebecca gets lost in trying to balance so many genres in just one film. Ben Wheatley does a great job controlling the pacing, offering enough time to develop the main characters and the core relationship. However, the tone changes are far from being well-executed, leading to an utterly absurd, rushed, convoluted last act out of nowhere that raises logical questions and leaves the viewer with a false sense of uncertainty. A well-structured, entertaining first half partially compensates for the weirdness that overflows the second part. Lily James and Armie Hammer deliver great performances, as does Kristin Scott Thomas, but the production design (supported by terrific costumes) steals the spotlight. Clint Mansell's score doesn't go unnoticed, but its placement is exceptionally inefficient. In the end, the attempt at creating a horror atmosphere with the "haunted" mansion storyline is so anti-climactic that I can't wholeheartedly recommend this flick...Rating: C

Review title: Provides a serviceable update to a classic story for the uninitiated but little more than forgettable thrills for everyone else
Review_body: "Rebecca" is a romantic thriller based on the novel of the same name by Daphne du Maurier. Starring Lily James, Armie Hammer, and Kristin Scott Thomas, it provides a serviceable update to a classic story for the uninitiated but little more than forgettable thrills for everyone else.After their brief courtship in Monte Carlo, the wealthy Maxim de Winter (Armie Hammer) and his new wife (Lily James) move over to Manderley, the large estate of de Winter's family in England. As she tries to adjust to her new life with the upper class, Mrs. de Winter frequently rubs shoulders with Manderley's stern housekeeper Mrs. Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas), who notifies the former of the untimely death of Mr. de Winter's previous wife Rebecca. Eventually, Mrs. de Winter starts to realise that her husband is not entirely over Rebecca's passing and suspects that her haunting presence still remains at Manderley.There have been various mediums for which Daphne du Maurier's classic 1938 novel have been adapted, ranging from a radio play read by Orson Welles to Alfred Hitchcock's Academy Award winning 1940 feature film. The latter example is probably the most recognised version of this story, as it was helmed by an acclaimed director who became a respected Hollywood figure as a result of its success. Having not read the novel myself, I will be using Hitchcock's film for comparison with this one. With that in mind, this modern 2020 adaptation feels like an inessential and inferior rendition as it sacrifices too many artistic licences for the sake of appealing to today's audiences. Gone is the subtle haunting atmosphere of Hitchcock's film and in its place we have instead surface level imagery obviously intended to provoke the viewer into thinking that something is amiss right away. Sure, this may make the film slightly easier to follow, but it feels like a major part of the original story's identity has been compromised. This lack of imagination may be the sad result of most people today finding it too boring to appreciate the importance of building suspense, which is a huge shame considering the story is littered with moments that revel in such a technique.It feels unfair to compare a director like Ben Wheatley to that of the legendary Alfred Hitchcock but it seems like I have little choice here. Although Wheatley is clearly trying hard to make the film look as nice as possible with creative production design and interesting choices in cinematography, he seldom uses these to his advantage when telling the story. Most of the time it feels as though he is overcompensating for his inability to recapture that feeling of suspense that Hitchcock's film excelled at. Hitchcock was known as "The Master of Suspense" so naturally these are big shoes to fill, but there were barely any moments this time around that actually felt filled with tension. As previously mentioned, this film does away with subtlety in favour of a more sensationalistic approach, which detracts from the gothic atmosphere the original was trying to create. That's not to say Wheatley's direction is terrible, it just distinctly lacks the unique flavour that Hitchcock brought to his film eighty years ago.The cast each did a decent job, with Lily James handling her role as the new Mrs. de Winter to the best of her ability. The chemistry between her and Armie Hammer wasn't always believable, but I did care enough about each of them to enjoy watching their escapades together. Hammer's performance, while fine, did feel somewhat off to me. I suppose it's just that he looks so American to me, and although the fake accent he used sounded okay, he stood out to me more as resembling a chiseled football quarterback rather than a member of the English upper class. On the other hand, Kristin Scott Thomas shines the most as Mrs. Danvers. Thomas plays the character with a more sinister undercurrent than that of Judith Anderson in the 1940 film. This made her role in the story considerably more prominent, as in the original there was a much slower build-up to the reveal of her true intentions whereas here it's plain as day she is plotting something from the very beginning.While I certainly wouldn't call it a bad film, this 2020 version of "Rebecca" doesn't have enough staying power to recommend it over previous iterations. Taken on its own, it's still a perfectly watchable thriller that perhaps modern viewers unfamiliar with the source material may find some enjoyment in, but anyone who has seen Hitchcock's film will leave convinced that no one else will ever succeed in topping it. It is unlikely this will be the last time we see this classic story adapted into a film, so hopefully future filmmakers will have the hindsight to understand what made it so special in the first place.I rate it 6/10

Review title: More of a soap opera but still decent enough
Review_body:
It is targeted at a modern audience who can encounter this actually quite terrific story. In its way its more glamourous than the Hitchcock film and build up more as a soap opera rather than a romantic thriller. This is where the film mainly lacks and no I don't compare it to the "Original" but that interpretation just worked better for me. This is however not a bad film either. Acting wise it was decent. Armie Hammer was well chosen for this kind of role and played it fine. Lily James had the looks but I am still not too sure of her talent especially in such complex roles as the one of Lady De Winter. She did her best, but it was not a performance to write home about.
The best performance came from Kristin Scott Thomas. You can blame her for being a bit overthetop and her character being a bit too cartoonish but she held herself well against that and a bit of both is also needed for that role. The look was great, sometimes just too perfect and too clean. Nice costumes and great art direction. A fine score by Clint Mansell. Its an okay film but not something that the world needs. At least it was decent entertaining with some atmospheric moments

Review title: Never read the book and didn't see the original
Review_body: I liked this. I know a lot of people didn't but since I didn't read the book nor did I see the original film I have nothing to compare this to. Taking this at face value I thought it was well acted and interesting. The only issues I have are this:Armie Hammer - they are still trying to make this guy a thing and despite having movie star good looks he's a dud. And now that some disturbing facts have come out about his personal life it's hard to watch him on screen without thinking he's a cad. He has all the elements and looks good on paper but he just doesn't translate on screen.Kristen Scott Thomas is a good actress or is she? She only plays dour angry characters. Her face rarely changes expression. She's wooden and stone faced. She's got a HUUUUGE nose that is really distracting and so she is hard to look at. Everything about her is severe and now that she's got some years on her all you see is the extreme wrinkling on her face and neck due to all the smoking she's done throughout her lifetime. All I see when she's on screen is the wrinkles so I can't focus on her acting. She truly comes across as someone who would be about as fun as a box of rocks.For me I need to like the actors I watch otherwise I can't get into their performances. For instance I LOVE Oliver Platt - even when he's playing an evil character you still like him and you can also see the acting ability because he truly seems like somebody who is a nice fun decent human being IRL so to see him play against that shows true acting. If someone is just naturally a dour killjoy in real life and then they play that on screen that doesn't really show me acting. Most people like to think that many of the so-called good actors in Hollywood are great but they only see them playing one type of character. Anybody would be good if they just played a heightened version of themselves on screen. I'm going to try and not compare this to its famous predecessor. To be honest, it's been so long since I visited this story, I'm hoping to be able to keep an open mind with Ben Wheatley's reimagining. With Wheatley's track record you'd think you're in safe hands, but even with the sinister elements to this story, it's an altogether different beast to films like Kill List, Free Fire, High-Rise and the excellent Sightseers. This is what they used to refer to in studio parlance as a 'Prestige Picture'. Big budgets, lavish sets, decadence dripping from the screen. Armie Hammer carries this weight well as the charming Maxim de Winter. He cuts that leading man presence. In fact the cast in general are pretty good, perhaps none more than Lily James, who's destined to become the new Mrs de Winter. You see Armie has recently lost his wife, Rebecca and is spending some time in Monte Carlo (see decadent), where he meets his bride to be as she's accompanying the ghastly Mrs Van Hopper (Ann Doud, of Handmaids Tale fame). He's rich and terribly polite. She's young, far from rich and also terribly polite. If it were to go on like this it'd be shockingly dull. It's not going to though is it. They fall in love, get married and head back to his country pile, Mandalay. And so we swap the sun-swept Med with its burnt orange sunsets and white washed walls for the darker, greener climbs of England. It's like stepping back (further) in time. This is all wallpaper though. As much of a presence that Mandalay is. It's it's inhabitants both alive and dead that bring it to life. The formidable Mrs Danvers (Kristin Scott Thomas) is the conduit for all things sinister. The housekeeper at Mandalay, still loyal to the departed Rebecca. She's a little frosty to the new Mrs de Winter, who finds herself living in the shadow of her predecessor, much like this film. Despite Mr de Winter seemingly looking to move on, it's clear he's trapped. The whole house is in a spell. Partly in a sense of duty, but mostly by Danvers. She's the lynchpin character and Scott plays her well, albeit a little obviously. She drives her new mistress bonkers, masking the issues her husband still harbours, as Mrs de Winter (she doesn't get a first name, that's only for Rebecca) finds she's impossible shoes to fill. It's a slick retelling of a maddening story and generally does everything right. It seems lacking heart and and grit though and when you're trying to crank up the psychological tension, that's a problem. Rebecca is an idea of perfection for much of the story and this film seems to be striving for that perfection too. Although it comes up short, that's not to say it's bad. It's a bit long. There's some duff character portrayals, Sam Riley's Jack Favell for one and I'm not quite sure what to make of Sleaford Mods frontman Jason Williamson singing in the kitchen as the toffs party at the ball upstairs. Don't get me wrong, it looks wonderful and the twists still lands with a punch. There's no denying the strength of the story and it grips brilliantly. I just think that modern cinema struggles with tales like this. Too clean, too much knowledge of cinematic tricks, not enough naive experimentation. This was always only ever going to be a rehashing. Wheatley is signed up for more frivolous drudgery, with a Meg and Tomb Raider sequel. I won't watch either, but I imagine they'll be a laugh. He seems all at sea here though.

'Rebecca' is one of Alfred Hitchcock's most admired films, so it takes guts to remake it in 2020. Anyone following in Hitch's footsteps is sure to be vilified for it. But let's be honest: this is not really a remake of a Hitchcock movie, but a new film version of a novel that has been adapted for the big and small screen several times.I think this version is a very decent one. For one thing, it looks gorgeous. The locations, the clothes, the cars: it's a feast for the eyes. Lead actress Lily James looks the whole time as if she is modeling for a '30's fashion magazine, which is nice. Apart from the looks of the film, the screenplay is also good. Then again, with Du Maurier's material it's hard to go wrong. 'Rebecca' is a story containing everyting it takes for a good film: suspense, character development, an improbable romance, sinister atmosphere and a spectacular ending. The fact that the deceased title character of the film hangs as a shadow over everything that happens, is what made Hitchcock's film such a good movie. But the same goes for the 2020 version.Director Ben Wheatly had to follow in Hitchcock's footsteps, but the lead actors have Lawrence Olivier and Joan Fontaine as examples - both with formidable reputations. I think both did quite well. The emphasis in this film is less on Maxim de Winter. So Armie Hammer's part is secondary to that of Lily James as Mrs. de Winter, the simple girl marrying a rich aristocrat. She succeeds quite well in combining innocent vulnerability and female attractiveness. But the show is stolen by Kristin Scott Thomas as the creepy Mrs. Danvers, the housekeeper of the De Winter estate, who radiates hostility while staying polite.After I watched this movie, I put the dvd of Hitchcock's 1940 version in the player. It had quite some nice Hitchcockian moments, but at the same time the melodrama is dated, the acting is stiff and the black & white doesn't do justice to the splendour of De Winter's estate. So in my opinion, the new 'Rebecca' is an enjoyable update.

As with Netflix's remake of THE BOYS IN THE BAND I'm wondering: why? The revision doesn't add much that's new - a glamorous cast, lovely locations and colour in place of black-and-white. The story is meant to be "timeless", but aren't there any new stories out there waiting to be filmed?Mrs Danvers is the key character. In the 1940 version her obsession with Rebecca was threatening and creepy - it was even possible to read in a lesbian undertone. Kristin Scott Thomas is heroically starchy and becomes subtly sinister, but this year's script makes her more patronizing than obsessive, and the battle between her and the new wife is more a power struggle rather than a study in psychosis.Lily James gives us a feisty Mrs de Winter, but Armie Hammer's transition from attentive boyfriend to absentee husband is unconvincing (his English accent suggests he was voice-coached by Prince William). The melodramatic climax lifts the plot out of a rut but, far from satisfying, it is almost ludicrous. Times have changed, and maybe REBECCA is a bit too dated, and a bit silly, for today's audience. Dated and silly doesn't usually spoil an Agatha Christie remake (looking forward to Kenneth Branagh's new DEATH ON THE NILE) but it doesn't work for this Daphne du Maurier adaptation.

That's the sound of this version losing steam just before the end, relative to Hitchcock's 1940 Academy Award winner.
Otherwise, that's the worst I can say about it. Good presentation of the much-loved, much adapted classic novel.
There are nightmarish bits and sequences added here that are not in the earlier film which are on the one hand a novel and original insertion but maybe ultimately gimmicky in their excess, as The New Mrs de Winter's waking life is more terrifying than the relative insubstantiality of mere dreams. There are no glimpses of Rebecca's ghost running down corridors in Hitchcock, yet her presence is constantly, oppressively. almost palpably present.
Another thing this really has going for it is inclusion of the novel's key plot point, which Hitchcock could not use due to the moral prohibitions of the Hollywood Code then in place, but if anyone could pull off getting round that it was Hitchcock and a stellar team of screenplay writers and adapters
Armie Hammer certainly looks the part of a 1930's aristocratic millionaire hunk but lacks the fire of Olivier's impassioned performance. Lily James gives an admirable current day performance, almost the performance Joan Fontaine would have given if she were a contemporary actress in our contemporary cinema. Ann Dowd as the future New Mrs. de Winter's former protectress/employer, an affected Grande Dame spinster is equally delightfully detestable as 1940's great character actress Florence Bates. 1940's George Sanders is simply irreplaceable in any role he ever took, but Sam Riley manages to hold his own doing it his own way.
Then there's Kristin Scott-Thomas. If anyone was ever up to attempting a role Dame Judith Anderson made a byword, it's her, although Agnes Moorehead did it in a radio adaptation, which also has to be entered in the competition for who did it best. Not blessed, in this case, with the Dame's renowned, shall we say, lack of beauty, instead Ms Scott-Thomas compensates by breathing all the more fiery venom, while remaining chillingly cool as a cucumber tea sandwich. She exudes the air of an evil Mary Poppins FROM HELL! .
Two BIG plusses for Hitchcock's: Franz Waxman's soaring score, and George Barnes Oscar-winning Beautiful B&W cinematography. Totally dark black shadows and unlit corridors draw and compel while simultaneously inducing terrible and inescapable fear, something random hues from a prism, no matter how dim, never can.
Back to the end, I know the original novelist Daphne Du Maurier wrote one ending for the book, and another for her own adaptation for a dramatic presentation, but did no work on any other of the film/radio/tv projects based on "Rebecca". I've never read the book, only seen the 1940 and 2020 movies, so have no idea if these follow either of her endings, but for me, between the two options presented by these two films, a Fiery End makes an incomparable impression compared to a soggy dunk in the Deep .

Rebecca
2020
12A
Director: Ben Wheatley
Starring: Lily James, Armie Hammer, Kristin Scott Thomas, Keeley Hawes, Bryony Miller, Tom Goodman Hill, Sam Riley etcOverall rating 81/100Rebecca is based on two newly weds called Mrs De winter (Lily James) and Maxim ( Armie Hammer) who upon arriving to his family estate learns about his past with his dead wife as secrets unravel. I really enjoyed Rebecca and I thought It was a cleverly crafted and entertaining movie so lets get started.First of all, the cinematography, set pieces, chemistry between characters and performances were fantastic. This movie looked visually stunning, the fantastically crafted shots with the atmospheric use of lighting and fog was just excellent, the set pieces were also beautiful, wherever this was set I want to go, the manor was absolutely breath-taking and was also a great place for multiple different parts of the manor and for the mystery to unfold. I thought the characters were very likeable and had excellent chemistry with each other. The character played by Lily James was so incredibly likeable you instantly sympathised with her situation before meeting Maxim and just had a fun and unique charm to her Lily James and Armie Hammer did fantastic performances here and had fantastic on screen chemistry with each other, there relationship felt very organic and real and they worked very well together, the performance from Kristin Scott Thomas was also excellent, she was incredibly unsettling and switched from sweet and smiley to menacing and cold so excellently she was a fantastic antagonist.My next few positives would be the mysterious and unsettling tone and the development of the mystery. I loved the mystery this movie created, the fact that they left so much out about Rebecca and her relationship with Armie Hammers character was excellent, I was genuinely intrigued and on the edge of my seat throughout, the movie also created a very unsettling tone, the constant comparison between Lily jame's character and Rebeca and the fact that the residents of the manor almost acted like she was still there was terrifying and gave the movie a supernatural feel to it that worked really well, I also loved how the mystery developed, I loved that they slowly revealed more and more things about Rebeca and the movie constantly left you questioning characters and leaving hints which was great and there was always enough new reveals to keep you constantly interested.My few negatives for the movie that bought it down slightly would be the unneeded characters, rushed character decisions and lack of depth to the more interesting themes. I felt like there was a few characters that didn't really contribute much towards the plot the lady who Lily james's was travelling with didn't contribute anything towards the plot and just felt very unnecessary to her character, I also found that the rushed character decisions between Maxim and Mrs de winter effected the pacing, the fact that their relationship moved so fast and too fast for a normal relationship it made the first act feel very rushed and more messy compared to the rest of the movie which didn't have these issues. I also found the movie lacked depth to it's more interesting themes and played it safe in places, the more interesting class themes were not explored and due to the class differences between both main characters I wish this was more well explored.My final few positives would be the clever links between the characters, plot twists and final act. I loved the links that the movie made between Lily james and her character as well as Rebecca, the constant comparison with her character almost unintentionally doing actions similar to Rebecca was excellently executed and the conflict that caused was pieced together perfectly within the film, the plot twists were also excellent, I never saw any of them coming and was genuinely surprised at the direction the movie went, but it raised the stakes and drama well and further cemented the movies cleverness and attention to detail with it's mystery leading to a shocking and entertaining final act that left an impact.Overall, despite playing it slightly safe with it's themes and a few character issues, Rebecca is a visually stunning, excellently acted and phenomenally crafted movie that has a mystery that will keep you constantly on edge and entertained.

I actually preferred Hitchcock's version to the novel; don't get me wrong, I loved the novel but in the confines of what Hitchcock had to work in he did a marvelous job at making one immersed in the story.The production value in this is well done. I even think the actors were the right choice for the roles but it seemed too modern even in its setting. The haunting aspect didn't come soon enough. I think it would have worked better if they started at the house in retrospect of the narration; though in the novel it was more of a remembrance after Manderlay burned down and they were living abroad.Gothic style doesn't necessarily mean dark and gloomy; everything in this is bright and shiney, for the most part, and that didn't bother me. 'Rebecca' to me was always a love story first and a psychological thriller second. The love story being between the new Mrs. De Winter and Max rather than Rebecca and Max because Max never loved Rebecca and Rebecca only loved herself, if even that. Mrs. Danvers loved Rebecca because they were basically the same person: cruel-hearted.Overall, it's a nice effort but doesn't stand up to the novel nor Hitchcock's version. What I think people could have gotten into is a prequel to 'Rebecca'. Or at least, I could.
