Ignore the harsh critics. This is a well-crafted film that deftly blends the beautiful and the dark gothic with skill and vision. Please understand that this is a film adaptation of the novel by 20th C gothic writer Daphne du Maurier--it is not a "Hitchcock remake" as others claim. And you really need to read the book to appreciate some of the subtleties of this film and its depiction of the narrative.
Some of the criticisms of the film are really about the novel itself. While perhaps Armie is a bit young to play Maxim, he did a marvelous job of conveying Maxim's inner demons which drove his mercurial nature that could be warm one moment and cold the next. I thought there was great chemistry with Hammer and James-a little more subtle than what some reviewers here wanted, but that is the way the book was written. DuMaurier writes their marriage as a bit paternalistic and refined but still loving and supportive (not Cathy-and-Heathcliff-combustion). The actors and director did a very good job of echoing that relationship with a little more passion thrown in for modern tastes. Lily James is perfect for the doe-eyed, ingenue role, and although at times her mousy, nervous deference was annoying, it's pretty darn close to the novel's depiction of her character. The show-stealer, though, was Kristin Scott Thomas who played her role of the sinister Ms. Danvers with frighteningly steely perfection. It's hard to make KST look unappealing, but the severity of her appearance and mannerisms here reflected the troubled darkness lurking beneath her polished veneer and wry, artificial smile. Brilliant performance.
What I really appreciated about this film was the incredible attention to detail and emphasis on the house as a reflection of the narrative. Everything from the ivy-patterned bed linens (invasive, suffocating, creeping) to the image of new Mrs.DeWinter blending in to the landscape in an ill-fitting green coat that was Rebecca's (she is disappearing in a role she does not fit) to the staff looking past her as they walk by (she is now the ghost in Manderlay), shows a thoughtful effort to visually echo the narrative tension. The cinematography-esp. the play of shadow vs light and dark/grey vs vibrant color- and the opulent sets and exotic locations make this film a feast for the eyes.
I don't agree with others who feel the second half was rushed. I wish the movie had been longer to allow for more development with some characters and plotlines, but it's very difficult to portray this complex, twisting story in a short period of time. Overall, it was an enjoyable film that I'll watch again. Just remember to view the film through the lens of an 82-yr-old novel, not a modern script.

Review title: Why remake a film when you have nothing of interest to add?
Review_body:
Right, so, since we so admire Daphne du Maurier's Rebecca we're going to make a new adaptation, only:We don't like the extremely shy personality of the protagonist, it's just not very 2020, so while she still remains somewhat insecure, we're basically making her a completely different person, who takes charge of situations, has no qualms about having pre-marital sex with Maxim, firing Mrs. Danvers (twice!), and breaking into doctors' offices in the middle of the night.We don't like the age difference of at least 20 years between the protagonist and Maxim de Winter, so scratch that.We think the story lacks excitement and action, because we either don't appreciate the subtle build-up of tension in the book, or we don't trust our audience to. Therefore we're adding extra intrige, an arrest, a bribe, and a criminal investigation that wasn't there before.Building on the previous point, come to think of it, we don't even like the thirties and the British mentality of that time, so let's only alude to that, in an almost comical way, and meanwhile have everyone practice only the bare minimum of stiff upper lip, while also giving away bits of information that aren't supposed to be shared with the audience until much later in the story.Lastly, we either don't think there's enough drama in the story or, again, don't trust our audience to pick up on it, so we'll throw in a last emotional scene with the protagonist and Mrs. Danvers, who subsequently throws herself off a cliff.Now, halfway through watching I figured I was probably unfairly biased, because I'm a big fan of the book and have already seen two film adaptations of it, my favourite being the 1997 one with Charles Dance and Emilia Fox in the lead, so I thought: maybe I should keep an open mind and just view this as a completely new interpretation of the book.
However, the crux, the axis, the pointe of Rebecca, no matter how else you may interpret it, is the lack of communication and making of assumptions between Maxim and his second wife that causes the wildest misconceptions on both sides and gets dramatically revealed near the end. The protagonist's very shy and insecure personality, the age difference between her and Maxim, and the obsessive adherence to decorum of the time actually go a very long way in explaining how this can happen in the first place. Leaving all these factors out, or at least diminishing them severely, and also giving away too much along the way (like the early mention of Rebecca's note) chipped away at the mystery and the suspense and therefore took away a lot from the eventual reveal. The reveal which, by the way, seemed to kind of "got over with" as quickly as possible, so the train of events could get picked up again.In conclusion: it's as if the original story first got wattered down in essentials and then enhanced again by the addition of a lot of unnecessary drama. I don't see what this film was supposed to be adding.I still award two stars because there was one alteration I rather liked: the fact that Mrs. van Hopper was on to what the protagonist was up to. When you think about it, that actually makes a lot of sense, because in a hotel like that there would be a lot of gossip and the comings and goings of Maxim de Winter would definitely not go unnoticed, as, for some reason, they did in the novel.
Also: I liked Keeley Hawes as Maxim's sister.

Review title: Maxim and Mrs. de Winter II's Relationship was Ruined
Review_body:

Throughout most of the book, Maxim is reserved and standoffish toward the second Mrs. de Winter. Although he could be witty and playful, there was always a solid barrier between them. That's what made the scene where Maxim finally confesses what happened to Rebecca so potent. Finally, they (Maxim and the second Mrs de Winter) are able to be intimate because Maxim has let down his barrier.

There are a few moments of emotional distance between them, but the constant physical contact between them took away from the tension, loneliness and doubt that was so apparent in the book. Review title: A Very Meh Visit to Manderley
Review_body: 'Rebecca' is one of my favorite books so I am always excited when a movie adaptation is released. This version of Rebecca missed the mark. Armie Hammer, while quite dashing in his own right, is no Laurence Olivier. He lacks some of the character's brooding sophistication and mystery and seems a bit too young for the part. (Hammer is about ten years younger than the Maxim character as written by Daphne DuMaurier.) In the book and the 1940 Hitchcock adaptation, the 20 year age difference between Max and The Second Mrs. DeWinter gave the relationship an air of old time romance and tentativeness that added to the suspense. The more obvious physical intimacy between Max and his new bride in this iteration is a surprising, interesting and not wholly unwelcome revelation but one that does not stay true to the essence of the original story. Lily James as The Second Mrs. DeWinter is respectable, as is Kristen Scott Thomas as the unhinged Mrs. Danvers but I wish they had both played their roles with more intensity. Compared to the performances by Joan Fontaine and Judith Anderson, respectively, the new takes on the characters lacked passion and wound up feeling anemic. (Anderson is downright spinechilling as Danvers in the 1940 version so I imagine her shoes are hard to fill.) This version also lacked the necessary moodiness, suspense and depth of the original, and the pacing was off. Some scenes in the beginning dragged out at the expense of more key scenes especially in the end, which felt rushed. And the ending (read: last two minutes) is AWFUL. It is a total departure from the overall tone of DuMaurier's novel. The characters go, well, completely out of character and honestly, this kind of ruins the whole film. On the upside, the scenery is lovely and there are adorable dogs in supporting roles. While it's worth watching, the 2020 version of Rebecca cannot hold a candle to Hitchcock's pre-WW2 masterpiece. I don't care to go back to this Manderley again.
A bit more suspense would have been good but in general it's a good movie.

Review title: Do not go into this thinking it's a remake of the 1940 movie
Review_body: I've been reading reviews and the single biggest reason people don't like it is because they are comparing this to the 1940 classic movie by Hitchcock. This is simply another book adaptation. With a couple of major differences, this sticks to the book very well. It's not without problems, but I must say, the few great aspects of this film are so good that they enhance the whole experience and make this deserving of a higher rating.Starting with the negatives so I can gush over Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas for the remainder; I must say the movie had serious pacing and editing issues. Some scenes were too short, cut abruptly to the next and seemed misplaced. It's like they shot 100 scenes, and just cut and pasted them one after the other. My other issue with this movie was the soundtrack. Hearing modern songs just takes you out of the movie. And the suspense music that plays loudly whenever you're supposed to be on the edge of your seat does the exact opposite. I truly believe the movie would have benefited from less music. Let the silence add to the unsettling nature of this story.Then we have the issue of tone. The famous Daphne Du Maurier book navigates the transitions between romance, thriller and mystery perfectly. There's an air of darkness everywhere, and it's mainly because you're in the mind of the main character when she's being harsh on herself and anxious about everything. That anxiety is translated onto the screen by one means: Lily James. That's it. The movie doesn't do anything to help her. The color are bright, the costumes are beautiful, the soundtrack is sexy... I wanted more torture, more anxiety. The only time I got that was when Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas were together on the screen. More on that when I write about what I loved about it.The last issue I had with this was Armie Hammer. It's not about his age, yes he's not 42 like the book - but it's him in general. He's basically eye candy, and I couldn't help wonder what it would have been like if someone with actual acting abilities had played Maxim. He didn't exactly play the quiet, depressed, powerful man. He was just a bland, rich, handsome dude. He didn't command respect and he wasn't mysterious. I can't really think of anyone who would have done this role justice, at least not anyone who's around Armie's age. I keep thinking of Alexander Skarsgård, but he's older. Also, what was that accent? He just sounded like someone who was trying to sound old Hollywood.Now, off to the good bits. The good bits are so good that I kind of want to re-watch this movie multiple times just to witness them again.Lily James was the single best thing about this movie. She's proven she's a talented performer multiple times now, but this is a difficult character to play. In the book, you understand her because you're literally reading her thoughts. To translate that into a performance is a daunting task which I believe she absolutely nailed. The nervous, shy quality of her character in the beginning of the film came across as authentic. To credit the writers, this was also because of scenes like her dropping the money when trying to bribe the staff or walking in front of a group picture being taken, etc.Then gradually, this character grows and matures. It's so subtle that you can't really decide when exactly it happened. But when it's half way through the movie and you go back to the start, it's so apparent. This is the single best development I've seen in recent years. There is no "I have to come into my own and be a woman warrior" moment. It just happens organically, and that's in a large part thanks to Lily James. She play someone insecure, unsure, and vulnerable who matures into the person that fights for what she wants brilliantly.Then, the best thing about the movie: When Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas appeared on screen together. Their scenes were intense, unsettling and charged. Lily's body language, the actual terror and discomfort in her manner and Kristin's powerful presence and haunting gaze was just the best thing. I would watch a whole 2 hour movie with these two just staring at each other! The scene where the second Mrs De Winter finds Rebecca's room and Mrs Danvers shows her around is the best scene of the entire movie. The colors are just right (the icy blue tone of the room, Lily wearing a blue/green shirt, Mrs Danvers in navy blue) gives you the sense of coldness, the acting is top tier and the dialogue is brutal. To think that they have these actors to work with, and can actually create scenes like this that have you hold your breath throughout and didn't utilize that is disappointing.So to sum this up, I enjoyed this film for what it was. A Netflix movie. It's clear they didn't want to make an Oscar-winning film. (They really could have, though) This is a romantic mystery, not thriller. The editing is problematic, and Armie Hammer does nothing but to be tall and handsome. However, the movie has a secret weapon in Lily James, and a winning combination of her and Kristin Scott Thomas. I'd say the whole thing is worth the watch just for these two. My 8 rating is simply because these two were beyond excellent.

What is the reason for making a new adaptation of a literary work? That is the question every filmmaker must ask himself before facing this task. Apparently, the director and scriptwriter of this new version of "Rebecca" never asked themselves; or if they did, they found answers to that question they could not transcribe in images and on the film itself.
If it was just showing scenes in the south of France on screen: welcome; serves as a tourist reference. But by trying to approach the book with "more fidelity" than Hitchcock did, they managed to get even further away from the Daphne du Maurier story.
"Rebecca" is a gothic novel, something that the makers of this version seem to be unaware of; or maybe they don't know the meaning of "gothic" or how it is translated into a movie.
The answer is simple: see the 1940 film by Hitchcock, which, even affected by the implacability of the Hay's code, not only manages to reflect the essence of the novela, but also transcends as a classic, a masterpiece of cinema.
This mess is just that: a mess. A subset of mediocre performances coupled with poor production (it is not known why, because this film obviously had a much larger budget than Hitch had). And the two main characters are a disaster. Lily James (not a bad actress, let me clarify) all the time overacts her role as a shy and insecure creature, to the point that it becomes very annoying. Armie Hammer is pure vanilla, without a trace of guilt, problems and insecurities; a pretty face to wander around the screen from time to time and attract sighing damsels. Mrs Danvers is stripped of all the sexual ambiguity that the novel, and the 1940 film, subtly suggest. Honestly, the performance of Scott Thomas is the only reason anybody could claim for watching this film, and even her is limited excessively by the script.
The ending of the film is really so out of character and far from the novel that it is, in itself, tragic. The reality is that this film is neither a romantic comedy, nor a mystery film, much less Gothic at all, as it is the novel on which it is based. So, what is it? Well, you don't know: it wants to be everything (perhaps to appeal to a larger audience), but it is nothing. Rather, something is: a disaster.

Review title: Not as terrible as all these reviews say
Review_body: So Rebecca follows the whirlwind romance and and subsequent complications of Mr. Maxim De Winter (Armie Hammer - I know 😬😖) and his new wife (Lily James). This film is an adaptation of the novel of the same name, and follows the new Mrs. De Winter as she attempts to fill the shoes of the mysterious, alluring, and tragically deceased late Mrs. Rebecca De Winter.This film is a beautiful period piece with fabulous cinematography, and very textured settings. It's kind of a slow burn, and definitely takes you on a ride. However, I felt that the pacing was very stunted, and alternated wildly between sprinting and walking painfully slow. The mystery of the story is doled out carefully, and the tidbits the film gives you make you work for them in patience for sure.Although this film has been generally panned online, I actually kind of enjoyed it. May have been because I set the bar pretty low, but it was still an enjoyable experience.A word of warning - don't let the trailer fool you. This is not a psychological thriller mystery - although it certainly has its moments. It's more a frantic and super tragic love story, where you just feel bad for Lily James because *nobody is nice to her at all* which is super tragic.All in all, 7/10 - would recommend if you're interested, but wouldn't try to make you watch it if you didn't want to.

Review title: Not very good adaptation, but it's entertaining, I suppose
Review_body: If you're familiar with the book, you'll find yourself becoming frustrated extremely quickly. For example, only the very first scene of the first ten minutes happens as it does in the book.This had real potential to be a good film but, sadly, it's not.

Didn't convey many of the cornerstones of the original film... for example, Max de Winter (Armie Hammer) seems distracted when you first meet him. He's not tortured and complicated like in the original. He lacks subtlety in the way he courts the young girl who becomes his second wife. When later they are married, his many outbursts seem unreasonable and though it hints at a complex backstory, that is never explored further by the film maker. In the original, their stories interweaved together to create a tapestry of intrigue centred around the house. In this, the house just served as a location where it all takes place. It has no intrinsic value in and of itself.Lily James was too naive and helpless to have ended up in a situation like that, manipulated at every turn, by all and sundry. At least in the original, Joan Fontaine had one eye open to all the predations that might await her as she joined Manderley. The new version has that character completely devoured by circumstance only for her to rise to the occasion in the latter half of the film which seemed unlikely at best and risible at worst. Kirsten Scott Thomas was probably the best thing in the film. She holds her own against the original Miss Danvers with her cold implacable exterior and distorted devotion to the former lady of the house. All in all, 3 stars for costumes and set design but this version doesn't hold a candle to the former. Check out Hitchcock's classic instead.

Review title: Not the book, but I liked it more than Hitchcock's
Review_body: Comparisons between the versions are unavoidable.It's pretty much impossible for a movie to take the time and care required to properly build up the tension created in the novel, that's why I never really took to Hitchcock's version. It felt like a SparkNotes of the book to me. A highlight reel of plot points without the required buildup of tension.Rebecca (2020) could equally benefit from perhaps another 20 minutes of run time to build tension, but the time it does use was in my opinion more effective than Hitchcock's even if some of the dramatic devices were less subtle than I would have liked. Read the book if you can, it's a masterpiece but if you only have 2 hours this is worthier of your time than most movies.

Review title: If you want to read the book, read the book
Review_body: Such a shame a good movie like this is getting bashed by people who read the book and are hoping the movie lives up to their imagination. I did not read the book and thought the movie was a breath of fresh air from the mindless Super Hero, Zombie, and Dystopian movies that are constantly coming out. Yes, it was a remake of 1940 movie, and is based on a book... Could it have been better? That's not for me to decide.But as someone who knew nothing about this book/plotline, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. My family and I were guessing throughout the movie what was going to happen, and the plot twists were great and took the movie in directions we were not expecting. Things at the end progressed a little quicker than I would have liked. I thought some of the scenes at the end could have been drawn out and developed more... But then again, the movie was already over two hours long. It's impossible to capture every detail of the book in a movie. I do not know what all was cut, but we thoroughly enjoyed this movie, and we walked away from it feeling like this is one of the best movies we've watched this year.

ABSOLUTELY LOVED IT!!! A wonderful adaptation with perfectly cast archetypes of powerful women, the men paled by comparison which was a welcome contrast between 1940 and 2020 direction as well as a spotlight on how well Du Maurier channeled timeless female strengths 80 years ago!For me the garish yellow suits the alfa males cowardice; fear of the past, of betrayal and of losing face. This actor was very close to the Maxim in my mind conjured from re-reading the book a 1000 times; handsome, commanding, hotheaded... weak, petty and insecure defined by privilage rather than character.We are not meant to love nor fear Maxim, he is an object of pity; a male in distress. It is the simpering, unnamed heroine who defeats her dragon, embraces her dead rival, rescues her man and lives on...The book strikes a chord with women and this film highlights and celebrates girl power where Hitchcock placed artful, broody shadows, perhaps to keep the book within his social lens and time.Comparing Netflix with old Hollywood is absurd and unfair, the critics are trapped in Hitchcock's vision not Du Maurier's book and have missed the magic of this telling... obviously nothing can touch the 1940 masterpiece however this film, in many ways is more honest towards Du Mauriers cunning flip of stereotypes which shocked her generation and helped to shape and define mine.

Why was this girl so persistent in making herself miserable living with abusive husband, abusive maid, being gaslighted in someone else's home? She was orphaned just 2 years ago so no explanation there. She had a job before she met her husband, so not there as well. Why? I really want to know. And if it's just a story about that anyone can became the victim of abuse, ok, fine, tell me the story. But nope, I'm not getting it. You can't call a film "romantic" or "ghost " story and give us an abuse story instead without explaining everything at all...
Stop comparing in to the Hitchcock one and just enjoy a new book adaption, then you'll love it.
